subject: Re: Dynamically discovering classes in a package. (was: Re: [junit] Why is it considered an error if there is no test in the file?)
msgSnippet: The convention most people use is to create a separate directories for their test code and business code. /myproject/src /myproject/test Some times you may
messageBody:
The convention most people use is to create a separate directories for their
test code and business code.

/myproject/src
/myproject/test

Some times you may still want to have utilities that have no tests in them
and another convention used is to have all of the test classes start or end
with Test.

/myproject/test/some.package/TestMyClass.java
/myproject/test/some.package/MyClassTest.java

Then you can create a file set based only upon the tests classes that you
want to run.

http://ant.apache.org/manual/CoreTypes/fileset.html

<fileset dir="${src.dir}" casesensitive="yes">
<include name="**/Test*.java"/>
<include name="**/*Test.java"/>
</fileset>


Good Luck,

~Danny


On 11/9/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> The ability to, with even just 80% reliability, get at runtime all of
> the
> classes in a package, without having to parse directories of source code,
> would be great for JUnit and other packages. Of course, Java makes 100%
> reliability impossible, but it would seem that examining the classpath
> could
> allow some magic to be worked. It would also seem the kind of problem that
> someone out there may have already solved. Anyone have a pointer? Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
> On 11/8/06, Kevin Lawrence <kev.lawrence@...<kev.lawrence%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
> >
> > On 11/7/06, Joseph Shraibman <jks@... <jks%40iname.com>> wrote:
> > > to the code it is testing. I'd like to create a junit ant task that
> > > just runs on my whole codebase, but not all of my classes will have
> > > test methods and I'll get an error for each class that doesn't (and I
> > > don't want to have to explictily add each class to my build.xml file
> > > when I add a test).
> >
> > If I were to try to tackle this, I'd be looking at how the ANT JUnit
> > runner is structured.
> >
> > Very approximately, it is like this:
> >
> > <junit>
> > <test>
> > <fileset />
> > </test>
> > </junit>
> >
> > The <junit> task runs all the tests handed to it by one or more <test>
> > elements. The <test> elements get their input from one or more nested
> > <filesets>.
> >
> > So rather than having JUnit /not/ filter out the non-tests, I'd have
> > that logic in either a custom subclass of <test> or a custom <fileset>
> > - or maybe even a customer selector within the fileset.
> >
> > Even if you don't sprinkle tests throughout your fileset, it's kinda
> > lame that you have to select tests by doing pattern matching on a
> > .class or .java filename. It's also error-prone as I have found out
> > way too many times.
> >
> > I have often wanted to do something similar myself but have never
> > gotten around to it. Let us know how it goes.
> >
> > Kevin
